headline: After Dumping the A380, Airbus Bets on Smaller Jets
summary: European plane maker Airbus for two decades was the biggest champion of the world’s largest airliners. After dumping the A380 superjumbo earlier this year, the jet maker is all but ceding the market for the very-biggest airliners to rival Boeing.

headline: Corrections
summary: Corrections

headline: The Stock Buyback Panic
summary: Repurchases reallocate under-utilized capital to more efficient purposes.

headline: Fed Chairman Powell Sees No Need to Change Rate Policy
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell said in a ‘60 Minutes’ interview that the U.S. economic outlook is favorable and that the economy doesn’t require higher or lower interest rates now.

headline: New York Senate, Assembly to Lay Out Their Visions for State Budget
summary: The New York state Assembly and Senate will unveil separate resolutions outlining their budget priorities, this week as they head into the final weeks of negotiation with Gov. Andrew Cuomo before the April 1 deadline to pass a budget.

headline: Ethiopian Crash Carries High Stakes for Boeing, Growing African Airline
summary: The crash of a popular Boeing airliner Sunday marks a major setback for Ethiopian Airlines and the plane maker, which has relied on the success of emerging-market carriers to fuel its growth in recent years.

headline: A February Revenue Surprise
summary: Federal tax receipts rose 10% from a year ago, in case you haven’t heard.

headline: Answering Taiwan’s Defense Call
summary: Trump can improve deterrence with an F-16V fighter sale.

headline: Nickel-and-Diming Us Out of Rhode Island
summary: An ill-designed paid family leave policy is driving some businesses to Massachusetts.

headline: How Realtors Add Value for Their Customers
summary: The National Association of Realtors is actively engaged in the effort to ensure consumers are benefiting from technological advancements in real estate as we look to maintain a healthy, competitive housing market.

headline: We Should Study Portugal’s Approach to Illegal Drugs
summary: I call attention to the Portuguese experience. Drug possession was decriminalized in that country in 2001. Since then, Portuguese drug use, HIV infection and drug-related deaths have diminished.

headline: A Graffiti Legend Wins Praise From Unlikely Admirers
summary: Albert Diaz is a longstanding figure in New York City’s graffiti scene—long a scourge of mayors and police. But the artist’s distinctive campaigns and talent have helped bring him honors.

headline: Record Border Immigration Surge to Accelerate, Government Projects
summary: Nearly 180,000 more migrants traveling as families are expected to cross the border into the U.S. by May, according to an official estimate from the U.S. Customs and Border Protection.

headline: Central Banks Play a Game of Risk Management
summary: The world’s central banks, boxed in with few policy tools available, are engaged in a major policy reversal to ensure major economies don’t sink into unexpected recession.

headline: ‘The Great Firewall of China’ Review: The Chinese Cyber-Padlock
summary: The Communist Party censors the internet because of the web’s ability to bring large groups of people together for collective action.

headline: Pressure Mounts in Venezuela
summary: The U.S. says it will tighten financial sanctions in an effort to restore democracy.

headline: Impeachment and Your Investments
summary: How will the markets react as Democrats push to remove President Trump?

headline: Hand Trump an Anvil, Fellow Democrats
summary: The economy and the electoral math say he’s easy to defeat.

headline: There’s a Crisis at the Border, but a Wall Won’t Solve It
summary: Legal loopholes are behind last week’s sharp spike in alien apprehensions.

headline: When There’s Too Much Sun and Wind
summary: The biggest danger of renewable energy is overproduction.

headline: America’s Extremist Abortion Industry
summary: Why the party of ‘safe, legal and rare’ can no longer bring itself to oppose even infanticide.

headline: Energy Leaders Convene in Texas as U.S. Oil and Gas Output Surges
summary: America’s growth as an oil and gas superpower, and the uncertainties companies face due to disruptive technologies and regulations, are set to be buzzy topics at the annual CERAWeek conference, starting Monday.

headline: Economy Week Ahead: U.S. Retail Sales, Chinese Economic Data and More
summary: In the week ahead, the U.S. will see fresh data on retail sales, while China will release a combination of economic data for January and February.

headline: Trump Kept Allies at Bay in China Trade Talks
summary: President Trump is keeping European allies seeking details of the U.S.-China trade deal at bay, saying he isn’t willing to share the benefits of U.S. negotiations. That stance has drawn fire from allies and business groups who say the administration could strike a better deal with a unified front.

headline: If You’re Considering an Annuity, Start by Understanding What You Get
summary: A beginner’s guide to decoding annuities and deciding if one is right for your retirement plan.

headline: Algeria Strikes Ramp Up Pressure on Ailing President
summary: Pressure is mounting on Algeria’s President Abdelaziz Bouteflika to step down as workers at the country’s massive state oil and gas companies went on strike on Sunday and some opposition groups urged the military to intervene after more than two weeks of protests.

headline: NASA’s 2020 Budget Request Aims to Speed Lunar Exploration
summary: NASA is expected to request a budget increase of more than $500 million for moon exploration and related programs in 2020.

headline: ‘Captain Marvel’ Continues Superhero Winning Streak at Box Office
summary: Walt Disney Co.’s “Captain Marvel” saved the day at the box office this weekend, delivering 2019’s first bona fide blockbuster after several weeks of lousy returns.

headline: Antonio Brown Is Headed to the Oakland Raiders in Trade
summary: The Pittsburgh Steelers agreed to trade Antonio Brown, arguably the best receiver in the NFL, to the Oakland Raiders for a third- and fifth-round draft pick.

headline: Rural Sheriffs Defy New Gun Measures
summary: In swaths of rural America, county sheriffs, prosecutors and other local officials are mounting resistance to gun-control measures moving through state legislatures in Democratic-led states.

headline: Brooklyn DA’s Office Unveils Strategic Overhaul
summary: The Brooklyn district attorney’s office is set to release a plan Monday it says will fundamentally reshape its culture, including by asking prosecutors to incarcerate fewer defendants and use other ways to keep people safe.

headline: Technology ETF Celebrates Milestone Birthday
summary: The Invesco QQQ Trust, the exchange-traded fund that was once practically synonymous with the dot-com boom and bust, turns 20 years old this week.

headline: Indian Election Dates Set for April and May
summary: India announced the rolling dates for national elections, setting the stage for the world’s biggest democracy to decide this spring whether to leave popular Prime Minister Narendra Modi and his conservative party in power.

headline: Owners of Chrysler Building Reach Deal to Sell Tower
summary: New York real-estate firm RFR Holding and Austrian real-estate firm Signa Holding signed a contract to acquire the iconic building for a little more than $150 million, leaving a substantial loss for the current owners.

headline: Fast-Growth Chickens Produce New Industry Woe: ‘Spaghetti Meat’
summary: The poultry industry faces another product problem arising from birds bred for fast growth: Meat texture so squishy it’s called “spaghetti meat.”

headline: Delivery Apps May Take the Whole Enchilada
summary: Eaters’ loyalty may shift away from restaurants to their favorite food apps.

headline: U.S., China Near Currency Deal
summary: China’s top central banker signaled that Beijing and Washington are getting close to reaching a currency deal as part of their negotiations to settle a trade battle. As part of the deal, Beijing has vowed not to devalue the yuan to help exports.

headline: Even the NBA Has Issues With Social Media Now
summary: What if some of the things that have made the league so popular are the same things making players unhappy?

headline: NYC Council Bill Would Provide Free Legal Help to Businesses Facing Eviction
summary: New York City small businesses facing eviction could get free legal counsel under a new City Council bill modeled after a similar program for residential tenants.

headline: Europe’s Most Important Bond Edges Back Toward Negative Territory
summary: Germany’s 10-year government bonds, known as bunds, yielded as little as 0.04% recently, a microscopic return for investors and a sign of the increasingly bleak outlook for the European economy.

headline: Riskier Stocks Are Paying Off
summary: Investors are snapping up shares of companies with weak earnings, a sign many have shaken off last year’s jitters and are ready to re-embrace riskier stocks in pursuit of outsize gains.

headline: Rebel Ambush Kills Nine Myanmar Police Officers
summary: A rebel ambush killed nine Myanmar police officers and highlighted the sharp uptick in violence in the country’s strife-torn Rakhine state, where militants drawn from the local Buddhist community are fighting with the military.

headline: North Korea Eludes Sanctions, Buying Oil and Selling Arms and Coal: U.N.
summary: North Korea has punched a hole in the web of United Nations sanctions intended to pressure Pyongyang to give up its nuclear-weapons programs and long-range missiles, according to a report to the U.N. expected this week.

headline: Trump to Request $8.6 Billion for Border Wall in 2020 Budget
summary: President Trump plans to seek $8.6 billion for additional barriers as part of his budget proposal to be released Monday, a potential prelude to a funding fight.

headline: How Big Tech Has Powered Global Stocks
summary: Profits at Facebook, Alibaba and others are boosting stocks that got walloped last year.

headline: Massive Power Outages Turn Deadly in Venezuela
summary: At least 15 people have died as a result of a massive electricity outage that has crippled Venezuela, as doctors struggled to assist patients and the sale of basic goods was paralyzed amid rising political turmoil.

headline: How a Russian Gas Pipeline Is Driving a Wedge Between the U.S. and Its Allies
summary: The Nord Stream 2 undersea gas-transport project is a bone of contention with Washington, which fears it will make Germany too reliant on Moscow. “Angela, you got to stop buying gas from Putin.”

headline: Cannabis Drinks Confront a Serious Buzz Kill—They Taste Terrible
summary: Upstart companies tinker with ways to dial down ‘oily grass’ flavors and notes of dish soap, urine.

headline: Username and Password Hell: Why the Internet Can’t Keep You Logged In
summary: It’s torture typing in usernames and passwords for every site and app we use, and it’s only getting worse as we add more devices. The good news: Everyone knows it’s a problem, and they’re working on it.

headline: Omar and the Conspiracy Democrats
summary: Her colleagues portray the freshman as a naïf. But she has a clear and menacing modus operandi.

headline: Italy’s Controversial Crackdown on Migration Is Stemming the Flow
summary: Migration to Italy via the Mediterranean, once the biggest gateway to Europe for those fleeing war or poverty in Africa and Asia, has nearly ground to a halt, showing the effectiveness of controversial efforts by authorities to stop it.

headline: ‘I’m Addicted’; Why Food-Delivery Companies Want to Create Superusers
summary: Hungry for repeat customers who look beyond one-off discounts, food-delivery companies are striving to convert those who order meals or groceries as an occasional, luxury splurge into habitual users.
